Project Description  The Community-Based Early Childhood Development Project will 
enhance the development of young children between birth and 8 
years  of  age,  by  providing  holistic  interventions  on  improving 
health, nutrition, and psychosocial development. The Project is 
directly relevant to the human development needs of the Kyrgyz 
Republic  stated  in  the  Government’s  Comprehensive 
Development Framework and Education Strategy for 2010. It will 
also contribute to the attainment of the Millennium Development 
Goals (MDGs) to reduce infant mortality rate (IMR) and under-five 
mortality rate (U5MR) and sustain universal primary education. 
The Project will focus on the 12 poorest raions (districts), while 
ensuring that the extended program of immunization will cover the 
needs  of  all  eligible  children  in  the  country.  In  addition  to 
interventions in health, nutrition, and education, the Project will 
pay special attention to building the capacity of the ayil okmotus 
(AOs–village authorities) and communities to plan, improve, and 
sustain child development. 
   
Rationale  Young  children  suffer  most  in  times  of  economic  contraction. 
International  research  shows  that  poverty  has  measurable 
detrimental  effects  on  children’s  physical  growth,  cognitive 
capacity,  and  psychosocial  adjustment.  Long-term  impacts  are 
most severe when children are unprotected in the years before 
they enter school. Health, nutrition, and education directly impact 
the lives of young children in poor families. Targeted programs 
that  integrate  health,  nutrition,  and  education/care  for  young 
children offset the deleterious effects of poverty. Without targeted 
interventions, the majority of children in poverty will not develop 
fully  in  their  early  years,  thus  permanently  diminishing  their 
capacity  to  achieve  their  potential.  Recent  years  have  seen 
declines  in  budgets,  coverage,  and  quality  of  social  services, 
particularly in rural and remote areas. Remote health posts and 
schools  are  the  last  to  benefit  from  supplies  or  training 
opportunities. Basic indicators on child development in the Kyrgyz 
Republic  show  substantial  scope  for  improvement.  Early 
childhood  development  (ECD)  has  important  implications  for 
women as well since their lives are closely intertwined with their 
children’s. ECD interventions will reduce women’s time spent on 
caring for sick children. Increased access to affordable preschool 
programs  will  enable  women  to  avail  themselves  of  economic 
opportunities.   Reduction   of   iron   deficiency  anemia  (IDA) will

  improve  women’s  productivity,  and  reduce  pregnancy-related 
risks, including maternal mortality. 
 
Objectives and Scope  The  goal  of  the  Project  is  to  improve  health,  nutrition,  and 
psychosocial development of children between birth and 8 years 
of  age  in  the  12  poorest  raions.  Specific  objectives  are  to  (i) 
reduce IMR and U5MR, (ii) reduce iodine deficiency disorder, (iii) 
reduce IDA both among children and pregnant women, and (iv) 
improve the psychosocial development of preschool children. By 
improving  children’s  health  and  nutrition  status  and  increasing 
access to preschool programs, the Project can increase women’s 
economic  opportunities  outside  the  home.  The  Project  will 
contribute  to  the  attainment  of  the  MDGs  to  reduce  IMR  and 
U5MR  and  to  achieve  universal  primary  education.  The 
components and the strategies adopted under each follow: 
 
The child health and nutrition component will (i) ensure universal 
coverage  and  quality  of  immunization,  (ii)  improve  case 
management  for  major  childhood  morbidities,  (iii)  improve 
functioning  of  primary  health  care  posts,  (iv)  universalize 
consumption of iodized salt, and (v) introduce behavioral change 
to  prevent  IDA.  The  early  childhood  care  and  education 
component will (i) improve access of poor children to preschool 
programs,  including  state-run  preschools  and  community 
preschool programs; (ii) improve the quality of grade 1 education; 
and (iii) improve the quality of child care at home. The capacity 
building  component  will  (i)  develop  the  capacity  of  local 
governments and communities to plan, implement, and monitor 
ECD  activities,  and  (ii)  improve  collection  of  community  and 
central government data and monitoring of development indicators 
for young children between birth and 8 years of age.

Project Benefits and  Direct  beneficiaries  of  the  Project  are  about  148,000  children 
Beneficiaries  between birth and 8 years of age in the 12 poorest raions. In 
addition, support for immunization will benefit all infants in the 
country.  The  Project  will  directly  enhance  the  development  of 
children and their future productivity.  
The Project will improve the effectiveness and efficiency of child 
development services. Some services in the health sector have 
been unable to achieve their full potential due to gaps in training 
and irregular supply of essential drugs. By bridging the gaps, the 
Project  will  improve  the  effectiveness  of  existing  services  at 
minimal additional cost. The Project will also improve the cost-
efficiency of early education programs by introducing alternative 
community-based models to complement formal preschools, and 
improving child care at home.  
The Project will build the capacity of the AOs and communities. 
Many project activities will be implemented at the community level 
and managed by AOs. This focus on AOs and communities will 
improve governance by bringing activities closer to the intended

by providing–through a village initiative fund–opportunities for the

Risks and Assumptions  The  Project  involves  almost  no  technical  risk.  The  selected 
interventions have been tested and proven effective in the Kyrgyz 
Republic and internationally. The most significant challenge will be  
effective implementation through multiple ministries and central 
and local government bodies. A steering committee consisting of 
experienced representatives of concerned ministries and oblasts 
(provinces) has been established and will provide policy guidance 
to the Project. The Project provides for substantial training of AO 
representatives and assistance of the child and family coordinator 
during the first 2 years of project implementation. 
 
Another  challenge  is  sustainability  of  the  services  after  the 
completion of the Project. Maintaining the quality of primary health 
care and preschool programs will require predictable, timely, and 
adequate budget allocations. Recurrent costs will be about 1% of 
the national health and education budget. The Project will ensure 
that the Government develops sustainability plans for vaccines 
and essential drugs, which are the major needed supplies.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Kyrgyz Republic for the Community-Based Early Childhood Development Project. The 
report also describes proposed technical assistance (TA) for Institutional Strengthening for 
Community-Based Early Childhood Development, and if the Board approves the proposed loan, 
I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
2.  Young children suffer most in times of economic contraction. International research 
shows that poverty has measurable detrimental effects on children’s physical growth, cognitive 
capacity, and psychosocial adjustment. The long-term impacts of these effects are most severe 
when children are unprotected during the years before they enter school. Targeted programs 
that integrate health, nutrition, and education/care for young children offset the deleterious 
effects  of  poverty.  Without  targeted  interventions,  the  majority  of  children  in  poverty  will 
experience inadequate development in their early years, permanently diminishing their capacity 
to achieve their potential.   
 
3.  The Kyrgyz Republic has a population of 5 million, about 22% of whom are below 8 
years of age. The per capita income is about $300, the second lowest among Central Asian 
countries, and poverty is prevalent. According to the National Statistical Committee, 40% and 
47% of the population live in poverty in urban and rural areas, respectively. The health, nutrition, 
and education sectors have direct impacts on the lives of young children in poor families. These 
sectors were funded centrally during the former Soviet Union (FSU) and, until its final years, 
were relatively protected. The Kyrgyz Republic had achieved a high level of education and had 
developed  extensive  education  and  health  care  networks  before  independence.  However, 
budgets, coverage, and quality of services have declined in recent years. Rural and urban 
disparities are widening. Scarce resources are concentrated in the major cities and towns; 
training and supplies reach remote, impoverished rural health posts and schools last.  
 
4.  Social indicators of the Kyrgyz Republic show the effects of increased poverty and 
declining  public  investment  in  child  development.  Achieving  by  2015  the  Millennium 
Development Goals (MDGs) to which both the Kyrgyz Republic and the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) subscribe may be at risk. Major efforts will be required especially to meet the 
targets  of  reducing  infant  mortality  rate  (IMR)  and  under-five  mortality  rate  (U5MR)  and 
sustaining universal primary education by arresting the problem of increasing dropouts. The 
Project seeks to help the Government improve health, nutrition, and psychosocial development 
of young children and attain the MDGs. The Project framework is presented in Appendix 1. 
 
5.  The IMR remains high in the Kyrgyz Republic despite almost universal literacy and high 
levels of attended births (95% of deliveries take place at health facilities supervised by trained 
medical staff). Government statistics in 2001, which use the Soviet definition of live birth, show 
that IMR was 21.7 and U5MR was 29.7. According to the 1997 Demographic and Health Survey 
(DHS) that used World Health Organization (WHO) standard definitions, IMR was 61.3 and 
U5MR was 72.3. Both the Government and DHS figures on the IMR and U5MR were much

2 
higher than the European average.1 The DHS figures place the Kyrgyz Republic in the group of 
lower human development countries with weak health care systems and lower literacy. 
   
6.  Children’s nutrition status has deteriorated since independence. In addition to a general 
increase in poverty, the reduced availability of food subsidies targeted at children and meals 
formally provided through preschools has eliminated key nutrition sources for young children. 
The collapse of the production and distribution of fortified food has increased micronutrient 
deficiency.  According  to  DHS,  the  prevalence  of  stunting,  which  is  highly  correlated  with 
reduced cognitive performance, reached 29% and 30% in Osh and Naryn oblasts (provinces), 
respectively. The prevalence of iodine deficiency disorder (IDD) is increasing. The Government 
reports  that  the  number  of  IDD  cases  has  increased  by  8-10  times  in  the  last  10  years. 
International research has clearly and consistently demonstrated that an average of 13 IQ 
points is lost in iodine-deficient children living in areas where goiter is endemic.2 Iron deficiency 
anemia (IDA) is also highly prevalent: 48.5% of children below 3 years of age and 38% of 
women  were  anemic  in  1997.  Women  with  IDA  face  a  higher  risk  of  pregnancy-related 
complications that contribute to higher maternal mortality ratio. Mothers with IDA give birth to 
infants whose psychomotor and cognitive skills are diminished or developmentally delayed.  The 
school performance of children with IDA, is also affected. Among adults, productivity losses due 
to IDA have been estimated at 5-17% depending on the kind of work. Overall, micronutrient 
malnutrition in developing countries costs at least a 5% loss of gross domestic product.3 
 
7.  Many young children have not benefited from psychosocial development opportunities 
and  primary  school  dropouts  are  increasing.  Prior  to  independence,  preschool  institutions 
comprising full-day nurseries and kindergartens offered a package of child nutrition, health, and 
education services free of charge to more than a third of preschool-age children. However, 
many preschool institutions have been closed down. Rural areas are especially hard hit. Only 
one third of operating preschools are located in rural areas. The surviving preschools have 
started  charging  small  fees  to  compensate  for  reduced  state  support  and  have  become 
unaffordable to poor children. In 2000, only 7.1%, 3.6%, and 2.3% of preschool-age children in 
Jalal-abad, Osh, and Naryn, respectively, attended preschool. Parents have not been able to 
replace  the  functions  of  preschools.  Parents  in  rural  areas  lack  knowledge  of  child  care 
practices to stimulate children’s psychosocial development, and have little time or inclination to 
communicate or play with their children. A study conducted during Project preparation revealed 
that many young children in the Kyrgyz Republic are left unattended for most of the day. Four- 
year olds were with some caretaker only for 5 hours a day and spend the rest of the day alone.  
 
8.  Before,  extensive  preschool  coverage  resulted  in  children  joining  the  formal  school 
system already able to read and write. In contrast, most children now enter grade 1 unprepared 
either academically or socially. The average age at school entry has declined: in 1991, 27,200 
6-year-olds entered grade 1, and in 1999, 40,000 did. This suggests that grade 1 is increasingly 
serving as kindergarten and a school preparation class. The result is added pressure on grade 1 
teaching. According to the Government’s 2000 Education for All Report, the primary school 
completion rate is only 85%. This lower-than-expected completion rate is at least partly due to 
lack of preparation for school at entry. Children who attend preshool are more likely to complete 
primary school and show higher school achievement.

9.  The condition of poor young children and their families and deteriorating public services 
for children require effective early childhood development (ECD) programs. Investment in ECD 
benefits not only children and their families, but also society as a whole. Society benefits from 
greater productivity in later life. Investment in ECD can reduce the needs for and cost of future 
social welfare programs, and public expenditures in the health care system. Children who 
benefit from health and nutrition interventions and preschool experiences are more likely to 
enroll and persist in school, to be healthier, to need fewer social protection or criminal justice 
services, and to earn higher incomes as adults. Research shows a positive correlation of ill 
health as a child, with physical impairments and health problems later in life, all of which are 
burdens on health services. ECD also addresses an important societal concern of equity. ECD 
has larger impacts on deprived children than better-off children and contributes to narrowing the 
differences  in  development  at  the  beginning  of  life  among  children  of  various  economic 
backgrounds. This is especially important for the Kyrgyz Republic and other FSU countries 
where economic inequality is widening.  
 
10.  ECD also has positive impacts on women, especially mothers, since mothers and child 
health are closely intertwined. Improvements in child health results in less time needed to care 
for sick children and reduced costs of health care. Aside from the obvious benefits of improved 
health for both mothers and children, ECD interventions, especially increased availability of 
preschools, enable women to access economic opportunities outside the home. Provision of 
preschools releases women from full-time child care, and gives them opportunities to participate 
in the labor market and earn incomes. Reduction of IDA among pregnant women reduces 
pregnancy-related risks and contributes to overall improvement of women's health. 
 
11.  The Government has long recognized the importance of child development. The Law on 
Protection  of  the  Kyrgyz  People’s  Health  clearly  stipulates  the  state’s  responsibility  for 
protecting  children’s  right  to  living  conditions  required  for  sound  physical,  cognitive,  and 
psychosocial development, and the obligation of citizens to take care of children’s health, 
physical, cognitive, and psychosocial development. Investing in ECD is directly relevant to the 
basic human development needs of the Kyrgyz Republic as stated in the Government’s poverty 
reduction strategy and also the Education Strategy for 2010.  
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
12.  While the problems associated with ECD in the Kyrgyz Republic are challenging, most of 
them  have  well-established  remedies.  The  Project  will  select  the  most  cost-effective 
interventions in the areas of health, nutrition, and early childhood care and education consistent 
with ADB’s Policy on Education (2002), and Policy for the Health Sector (1999). ECD is a 
priority subsector under the education policy. The health policy prioritizes support for primary 
health care that benefits the poor and identifies priority, cost-effective health interventions. The 
sector/subsector analysis is presented in Appendix 2.   
 
13.    Child Health.  According to Government data, the major causes of infant deaths are 
acute respiratory infections and diarrhea–diseases that were responsible for 38.2% and 12.4% 
of all infant deaths in 2001. Causes of under-five deaths follow the same pattern. Child deaths 
due to these diseases can be prevented by quality primary health care. In the Kyrgyz Republic, 
primary health care providers consist of FAPs (primary health care posts) and Family Group 
Practices (FGPs). FAPs have feldshers (primary health care workers) and midwives and are 
often the only health care providers located in remote villages. FGPs have medical doctors in 
place. They provide primary health care services to people and supervise the FAPs. While 
FGPs  have  received  assistance  under  other  projects  in  recent  years,  FAPs  have  been

4 
neglected. Therefore, to reduce child mortality in rural areas, improving the FAPs will be crucial. 
Immunization  is  arguably  the  most  important  means  to  prevent  infant  deaths.  The  Kyrgyz 
Republic has maintained universal immunization for children, relying on vaccines funded by the 
Government of Japan and the Global Alliance for Vaccines and Immunization. However, this 
assistance is due to end in 2004. Given its fiscal constraints, the Government will need interim 
financial support to sustain universal immunization. The Integrated Management of Childhood 
Illnesses (IMCI) program was developed by WHO and UNICEF to efficiently reduce the severity 
of major childhood illnesses and deaths due to illnesses among children less than 5 years old. 
IMCI has been piloted in three raions, but not on a large scale for lack of resources. 
 
14.  Child Nutrition. The most effective means to prevent IDD and IDA is to promote use of 
iodized salt and iron fortification of staple food.4 Since 2001, ADB has been administering a 
Japan  Fund  for  Poverty  Reduction  (JFPR)  project  for  improving  nutrition  of  women  and 
children.5 The Project has contributed to production of iodized salt and iron-fortified wheat flour 
of  good  quality,  enforcement  of  the  universal  salt  iodization  law,  and  increased  public 
awareness  of  the  importance  of  using  iodized  salt  and  fortified  food.  The  Government 
introduced the National Program for Reduction of IDD for 2003-2007 (approved 9 December 
2002) to accelerate actions to prevent IDD. The main objectives of the program are to (i) 
achieve compulsory salt iodate fortification and refortification; (ii) increase the percentage of the 
population  consuming  iodized  salt  to  95%;  (iii)  prevent  industrial  salt  use  for  human 
consumption; (iv) conduct social mobilization for IDD prevention; and (v) train primary health 
care providers on IDD prevention, diagnosis and treatment. 
 
15.  Early  Childhood  Care  and  Education.  Expanding  early  childhood  education  is  a 
priority  of  the  Government  Strategy  on  Education  Development  to  2010.  The  number  of 
preschools will be increased and the curriculum will be reformed. The FSU model of full-day, 
full-service nurseries and kindergartens is expensive and beyond the financial means of the 
Government and poor families. Pedagogy used at the conventional preschools also need to be 
updated and made more child-centered. Several alternative preschool programs have been 
piloted  in  the  Kyrgyz  Republic6  and  the  Project  will  support  systematic  development  of 
alternative preschools in the community or at home to extend the access of poor children to 
preschools,  and  improve  grade  1  teaching.  The  combination  of  increasing  preschool 
opportunities and better grade 1 teaching will contribute not only to children’s psychosocial 
development  but  also  to  increasing  the  primary  school  completion  rate  and  learning 
achievement.  Even with increased availability of preschool programs, families will continue to 
be the primary child care providers, and the quality of child care at home will have significant 
impacts  on  child  development.  Therefore,  the  Project  will  also  aim  to  improve  child  care 
practices at home.

17.  Lessons  Learned  and  Special  Features.  The  Project  has  three  distinct  design 
features:  integrated  ECD,  multisectoral  and  decentralized  implementation,  and  community-
based  interventions.  Health,  nutrition,  and  education  are  interactive  determinants  of  child 
development, and programs to optimize child development should integrate these features. The 
integrated ECD interventions have been found to be more effective than isolated single sector 
interventions. Most ECD interventions by the Government or international organizations remain 
isolated and narrowly focused pilots, small in scale, often covering only a few raions. The 
Project will consolidate successful pilot interventions as an integrated package of ECD services, 
take  them  to  scale,  and  coordinate  multiple  agencies  to  achieve  tangible  effects.  The 
experience of ADB-financed ECD projects in the Philippines shows that strong leadership at the 
national  Government  level  is  crucial  in leading  a  multisectoral  ECD  project,  and  also  that 
activities entrusted to local governments are more likely to progress than those handled by the 
central government. The President’s office has been selected to be the Executing Agency to 
lead this multisectoral Project and to coordinate different ministries. A substantial part of project 
activities  will  take  place  at  the  ayil  okmotu  (AO,  village  authority)  level.  The  AO  and  the 
community will be entrusted with organizing community-based preschools. AO and community 
initiatives will be supported by providing grants from a village initiative fund (VIF). This model is 
based on a positive experience of the discretionary fund under the ADB-financed Social Service 
Delivery Project in the Kyrgyz Republic.  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Objectives 
18.  The goal of the Community-Based Early Childhood Development Project is to improve 
health, nutrition, and psychosocial development of children between birth and 8 years of age in 
the 12 poorest raions. Specific objectives are to (i) reduce IMR and U5MR, (ii) reduce IDD, (iii) 
reduce  IDA  both  among  children  and  pregnant  women,  and  (iv)  improve  psychosocial 
development of preschool children. The Project will contribute to attaining the MDGs to reduce 
IMR and U5MR and achieve universal primary education. The Project will also contribute to 
increasing women’s economic opportunities outside the home by improving children’s health 
and nutrition status, and increasing access to preschool programs.  
 
19.  The Project has three components. The child health and nutrition component will (i) 
ensure universal coverage and quality of immunization, (ii) improve case management for major 
childhood morbidities, (iii) improve functioning of primary health care posts, (iv) universalize 
consumption of iodized salt, and (v) introduce behavioral change to prevent IDA. The early 
childhood care and education component will (i) improve access of poor children to preschool 
programs including state-run preschools and community preschool programs, (ii) improve the 
quality of grade 1 education, and (iii) improve the quality of child care at home. The capacity 
building component will (i) develop the capacity of local governments and communities to plan, 
implement,  and  monitor  ECD  activities;  and  (ii)  improve  data  collection  and  monitoring  of 
development indicators for young children between birth and 8 years of age from the community 
to the central Government levels. 
 
20.  The Project will target poor children between birth and 8 years of age. Using poverty 
statistics, the Project will target the 12 poorest raions with poverty rate above 69% in 2001.7 
                                                 
7  Ak-Tala, At-Bashy, Jumgal, Kochkor, and Naryn raions in Naryn oblast; Chatkal, Toktokul and Toguz-Toro in Jalal-
Abad oblast; and Alay, Kara-Khulja, Chon-Alay, and Nookat raions in Osh oblast.

B.  Components and Outputs 
1.  Child Health and Nutrition 
 
21.  Expected outputs of the component are (i) sustained universal immunization of children 
in the country, (ii) expanded use of IMCI, (iii) universal use of iodized salt by households, and 
(iv) rehabilitated primary health care facilities.  
 
    a.  Sustaining Universal Immunization of Children 
 
22.  The Project will support the purchase of vaccines and procure equipment necessary for 
maintaining an effective cold chain from participating raion centers (i.e., principal towns) to 
primary health care facilities. The Government will be accountable for maintaining the cold chain 
from the vaccines' point of entry to the country to the raion centers, and for ensuring an 
adequate  supply  of  power  to  primary  health  care  facilities.  Considering  the  importance  of 
immunization  in  containing  IMR  and  infant  morbidity,  the  Project  will  finance  the  national 
requirements of vaccines for an extended program of immunization (EPI) from 2005 to 2008, 
and provide refrigerators at primary health care facilities and the Sanitary and Epidemiological 
Services.   
 
    b.  Reducing Child Mortality 
 
23.  IMCI  reduces  the  mortality  of  children  between  6  months  and  5  years  of  age  by 
addressing the common causes of child mortality–acute respiratory infections and diarrhea–and 
mitigating malnutrition. The Project will support the training of primary health care workers 
(feldshers) on IMCI in the project raions. In addition to the main clinical and nutrition module, the 
care module that will promote psychosocial development of children will be included as part of 
IMCI training. Piloting of the care module has started with support of UNICEF and WHO, and 
the Government will adopt the IMCI care module by the end of 2003. While training the FGP 
doctors on IMCI will be primarily the Government’s responsibility, the Project will provide for 
training about 25 doctors in the targeted raions. The Project will also support essential drugs 
and medical supplies required by FAPs to implement IMCI. Essential drugs at FAPs have been 
in short supply, although the situation is gradually improving. The Government has introduced 
corrective  measures  including  the  cofinancing  of  essential  drugs  by  the  Mandatory  Health 
Insurance Fund (MHIF). However, it will take the Government some time to allocate sufficient 
funds for the MHIF, and to increase the availability of pharmacies in rural areas. Therefore, the 
Project’s support is necessary as an interim measure.  
 
c.  Reducing IDD and IDA 
 
24.  The Project will support the national program for reduction of IDD. It will finance social 
mobilization, especially monitoring of iodized salt by communities and retailers. The Project will 
provide  salt  testing  kits,  and  information,  education,  and  communication  (IEC)  materials.  
Community salt monitoring has been piloted in Naryn oblast by the Swiss Red Cross and the 
JFPR project. It has increased awareness of the importance of iodized salt and the availability of 
iodized salt in the market. Support for IDA reduction consists of iron supplements–iron tablets 
for children and women and syrup for young children–as part of the essential drug package, and

7 
IEC activities. IEC will promote diets that would increase iron intake and absorption, discourage 
behaviors that inhibit iron absorption, and advocate implementation of nutrition policies. IEC 
materials on IDD and IDA which were developed under the JFPR project and by other aid 
agencies will be utilized in this Project.  
 
d.  Rehabilitation of Primary Health Care Facilities 
25.  Equipment  and  facilities  in  FAPs  are  in  serious  disrepair  and  affect  the  quality  of 
services for children. The maintenance of the primary health care facilities is the responsibility of 
oblast  governments,  which  often  lack  financial  resources.  This  subcomponent  will  aim  at 
rehabilitating the FAPs, which need major repair. It is estimated that 120 FAPs at most, need 
major repair. The Project will also finance the essential equipment in FAPs, which need to be 
replaced in the project raions.  
    
  2.  Early Childhood Care and Education 
 
26.  Major outputs of this component are (i) new community or home based preschools, (ii) 
improved grade 1 education, (iii) improved child care practices at home, (iv) revised standards 
for preschool programs, and (v) rehabilitation of currently operating kindergartens and a limited 
number of grade 1 classrooms. Community or home-based preschool programs will serve not 
only as instrument to impart psychosocial stimulation activities to children but also as efficient 
means to health and nutrition education.  
 
a.  Community and Home-Based Preschools 
27.  This subcomponent will help communities to develop cost-effective preschool programs.  
The  Project  will  support  (i)  child  and  family  coordinators (CFCs)  who  will  work  with  AOs, 
mobilize communities, and initiate preschool programs in the community; (ii) one resource 
kindergarten per raion as a resource center for community or home-based preschools; (iii) 
providing  instructional  materials  and  supplies  necessary  for  children's  activities,  and  other 
necessary supplies to AOs; and (iv) training for teachers of kindergarten preparatory courses, 
and community or home-based preschools, and monitoring their performance. The Ministry of 
Education and Culture (MOEC) will select one resource kindergarten in each raion among 
currently operational kindergartens. The resource kindergartens will have complete lending 
libraries  of  reference  materials  for  other  kindergartens  and  community  or  home-based 
preschools and will be used as training sites. Kindergartens that will serve as hub kindergartens 
to  advise  and  supervise  a  group  of  community  or  home-based  kindergartens  will  also  be 
provided with learning materials and in-service teacher training.    
 
    b.  Improving Grade 1 
 
28.  This subcomponent will improve the quality of grade 1 in primary schools, and ensure 
universal enrollment and completion of grade 1. Textbooks and learning materials are in short 
supply in many primary schools, and many grade 1 teachers have not received regular refresher 
training. The Project will provide (i) complete sets of textbooks and learning materials for grade 
1 pupils and (ii) in-service training for grade 1 teachers.  
                         
                        c.  Improving Child Care Practice 
 
29.  This subcomponent aims at improving child care practice especially parents’ knowledge 
of and skills in child care. The Project will support development of an IEC strategy for better

8 
child care, production of IEC materials, and training. IEC will focus on building awareness of 
family impacts on ECD, feasible activities at home for psychosocial development (e.g., verbal 
interaction, reading, and play), and nutrition education. This component, complementing the 
activities for reducing IDD and IDA, will provide a comprehensive package of key nutrition 
messages covering exclusive breastfeeding, complementary feeding, use of iodized salt, and 
intake of iron supplements. Parent education materials will be developed by a working group 
comprising representatives of MOEC, Ministry of Health (MOH) and other experts, assisted by 
an international consultant.      
 
    d.  Developing Standards for Preschool Programs 
 
30.  Standards  and  regulations  for  preschool  programs  have  not  been  updated  since 
independence  and  need  major  updates.  MOEC  proposes  to  develop  new  standards  for 
preschool  programs  including  state  kindergartens  and  nurseries,  community/home  based 
preschools, preparatory courses, and preschools run by nongovernment organizations (NGOs) 
or the private sector that meet world standards. The Project will support the development of 
standards by providing an international consultant for the advisory TA to work with the working 
group appointed and led by MOEC. 
 
e.  Rehabilitating of Grade 1 Classrooms and Kindergartens 
 
31.  Some schools and kindergartens need repair to create a safe learning environment for 
children.  The  Project  will  support  rehabilitation  of  selected  grade  1  classrooms  and 
kindergartens. About 30 kindergartens and 50 grade 1 classrooms will need major repair.  
MOEC will select the 50 schools based on geographic accessibility, quality of teachers, and 
possibility of offering preparatory courses for preschool children. The 30 kindergartens for major 
rehabilitation  work  will  be  selected  based  on  the  need  for  repair  and  capacity  to  support 
community-based preschools. 
 
3.  Capacity Building 
32.  This component will develop the capacity of AOs and committees to improve ECD by 
planning and managing ECD activities, and strengthen the Government capacity to monitor 
indicators  of  child  development.  The  outputs  of  the  component  are  (i)  community-based 
activities  for  improving  ECD  financed  by  the  VIF,  (ii)  strengthened  capacity  of  AOs  and 
communities to plan and carry out activities for child development with the assistance of CFCs, 
and (iii) improved monitoring of child development indicators. 
 
a.  Strengthening AO’s Capacity 
 
33.  The AO’s capacity to plan and implement project activities will be strengthened by 
training on management and by CFCs. CFCs will be selected on a competitive basis from the 
locality and hired on a contractual basis for 2 years and supported by the Project. Their main 
tasks are to (i) assist the AO to develop work plans for project activities carried out at the AO 
and  community  levels,  (ii)  mobilize  and  help  communities  establish  a  child  development 
committee and identify needs of their children, (iii) initiate new preschool and child activities, (iv) 
manage the IEC campaign, (v) review the project activities conducted at AO or community 
levels, (vi) monitor performance indicators and prepare project progress reports. The outline 
terms of reference of CFCs is attached as Appendix 5. CFCs are meant to support the AOs and 
communities  during  the  initial  stage  of  the  Project,  which  requires  intensive  community 
mobilization and IEC activities. After 2 years, CFCs' work will be transferred to existing social

9 
workers or another category of workers, which the Ministry of Labor and Social Protection 
(MLSP) is piloting in a few raions and is planning to introduce more widely in the future. 
Otherwise, AOs will support the CFCs from their own budget. The Project will support training of 
CFCs and social workers on community mobilization, essential topics on child development, 
project activities and administration. 
 
b.  Village Initiative Fund 
 
34.  The VIF subcomponent will provide the AO and communities with financial resources 
and opportunities to address their specific needs in ECD. Funds will be made available over 5 
years for the projects in the project raions that will have a direct, tangible, and positive impact on 
children between birth and 8 years of age. Communities will be eligible to apply for VIF financing 
through AOs; each application should not exceed $5,000. Project raions or  groups of AOs that 
wish to implement a project that will benefit children across different AOs can apply for VIF 
financing through the raion administrations. In this case, each application should not exceed 
$15,000 dollars. The community will share 20% of the project cost: 10% in cash and 10% in 
kind.  The  operational  framework  of  the  VIF  is  presented  in  Appendix  6.  VIF  will  become 
operational within 3 months of project effectiveness. 
 
    c.  Monitoring ECD Indicators 
 
35.  MLSP has been conducting the Social Passport Survey since 2000. It is an annual 
survey  to  update  the  database  on  the  economic  status  of  each  household  in  the  Kyrgyz 
Republic.  Social workers posted at AOs visit each household to collect data on household 
income and other welfare indicators, which are used to facilitate targeting of social assistance 
programs. A module on ECD indicators will be added to the standard Social Passport Survey 
questionnaire under the Project, which will allow key project output indicators for ECD to be 
regularly monitored. The data from AOs will first be compiled at the raion Social Protection 
Department; sent on to the oblast administration, which will compile the data for the oblast; and 
then submitted to the central Government. The results of analysis will be fed back to the 
concerned ministries, oblast and raion administrations, and AOs. To ensure quality survey data, 
the Project will support data management training for social workers in the targeted raions and 
MLSP staff in the raion, oblast, and central Government who are responsible for management of 
survey data. The Project will also assist the Government in computerizing such data. Once the 
quality of data enumeration is improved, each of the participating raions and oblasts will be 
provided  a  computer,  if  the  respective  government  agencies  agree  to  bear  recurrent  and 
maintenance costs for the computers and data management. 
 
36.  Apart from the regular social passport monitoring, surveys will be conducted at the 
beginning and end of the Project to establish the baseline and end values of ECD indicators. 
The survey will be designed with TA to allow rigorous evaluation of the outcome of project 
interventions.

V.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Project Benefits 
1.  Poverty Reduction 
 
58.  Investment in ECD results in improved human capital in the long run and high future 
incomes of individuals. The investment is especially effective among children from economically 
disadvantaged  families.  ECD  investments  targeting  poor  children  will  help  prevent 
intergenerational transfer of poverty. Large regional variations in the poverty rate and availability 
of poverty data at the raion level enabled the Project to adopt efficient geographic targeting of 
the poor population. The 12 targeted raions are the poorest, with poverty rates above 69% as of 
July 2002. Activities under the Project are also pro-poor, focusing on primary health care and 
community-based activities in rural areas. Except for support for immunization, which covers the 
entire child population in the Kyrgyz Republic, the activities concentrate at community-level 
interventions, including support for the FAPs the first health care contact point for the rural poor 
and preschool activities in rural communities. The combination of efficient geographic targeting 
and selecting pro-poor interventions will ensure that more than 50% of the project beneficiaries 
are poor.   
 
  2.  Strengthening Local Self-Governance 
 
59.  The AO is the lowest elected political body. At the level of the AO and the community, 
many Project activities will be carried out and substantial training will be given. This focus on the 
AO and the community will help improve governance by bringing activities closer to the intended 
beneficiaries, and improve efficiency by giving the communities opportunities to design and 
implement through the VIF, projects catering to their specific needs. The experience with an 
ADB-financed  ECD  project  in  the  Philippines  also  shows  that  activities  entrusted  to  local 
governments are more likely to progress than those handled by the central Government.    
 
  3.  Improved Effectiveness and Efficiency of Services 
 
60.  Some services in the health sector, such as IMCI, have not achieved their full potential 
due to remaining gaps in training and insufficient supply of essential drugs. The Government 
has been able to mobilize resources for training FGP doctors on IMCI, but has not been able to 
train feldshers, who are the first health care contact for the rural population. Essential drugs 
necessary for implementing IMCI have not reached all primary health care providers. Filling 
these gaps, the Project is improving the effectiveness of existing services at minimal additional 
costs. 
 
61.  The Project will also improve the cost-efficiency of preschools. Replicating existing state-
run  kindergartens  is  not  a  financially  viable  option  for  MOEC’s  endeavor  to  increase  the 
coverage of preschools. The annual expenditure per child in state-run kindergartens ranged 
from $60 to $100 equivalent in 2000. The Government budget that covers between 65% and 
90% of the expenditure, depending on the oblast, mostly pays for teachers’ salary.  By contrast, 
the Project expects that the annual recurrent expenditure per child of a community or home-
based  preschool  will  be  $30-40  following  an  initial  $1,500-2,000  investment  in  equipment, 
furniture, and learning materials.

17 
B.  Analysis of Economic and Financial Sustainability 
 
62.  The Project is expected to directly benefit more than 148,000 children between birth and 
8 years of age in the 12 target raions. Over 20 years, the beneficiaries will total 484,000 children 
and 368,000 pregnant women. In addition, the immunization subcomponent will cover all infants 
in the Kyrgyz Republic. The economic benefits of the Project will come from (i) savings in health 
expenditures due to fewer hospital visits, (ii) savings in education expenditures due to reduced 
grade repetition, (iii) productivity gains from an increased life-span and reduced mortality, (iv) 
productivity gains from improved education achievements especially through reduced dropout 
rates,  (v)  productivity  gains  from  reduced  IDA,  and  (vi)  social  protection  benefits  through 
improved social behavior. The estimated economic internal rate of return (EIRR) for the Project 
is 63.6%.  Because of practical difficulties in estimating them, the calculation did not include the 
benefits in (vi), or the benefits to children outside the project raions but who benefit through 
immunization and improved national ECD policies. The actual return will be higher when the 
excluded benefits are factored in. The EIRR is highly sensitive to assumptions made, especially 
external factors, such as the macroeconomic situation of the country, which will determine 
economic opportunities for the population. Therefore, even if the Project succeeds its achieving 
objectives, the high EIRR may not materialize due to external economic factors. The economic 
analysis is presented in Appendix 15.   
 
63.  The Project avoids introducing new functionaries in the Government payroll or facilities 
to  be  sustained  by  the  Government  budget.  The  Project’s  recurrent  costs  that  cover 
maintenance  of  facilities,  equipment,  supplies  (vaccines,  essential  drugs,  and  education 
materials), training, and monitoring will represent less than 1% of the national health and 
education budget over the forecast period of 20 years.10 The Project encourages cost sharing 
by the AO and the community. If their contributions are considered, the percentage will further 
decrease.  Major  recurrent  costs  are  vaccines  and  essential  drugs.  The  Government  has 
committed itself to financially sustainable procurement of vaccines. Essential drugs will be 
increasingly  made  available  as  the  MHIF  improves  its  performance  and  more  pharmacies 
become available in rural areas. Therefore, sustaining the project activities beyond the project 
period is expected to be within the fiscal capacity of the Government.  
 
C.  Environmental and Social Measures 
1.  Environment 
 
64.  The  Project  will  not  have  significant  adverse environmental  effects. Civil  works  are 
limited to rehabilitating of existing health facilities, kindergartens or grade 1 classrooms in rural 
areas. The Project will not procure potentially hazardous medical supplies such as syringes and 
needles. The Project will finance mostly preventive medical activities, which leave almost no 
medical wastes. The Government also has a regulation on medical waste management. Project 
supervision  will  closely  monitor  the  issue  of  medical  wastes  in  health  facilities  during 
implementation and introduce corrective measures if a problem is found.   
   
2.  Social Analysis 
 
65.  The Project does not have any adverse social impacts. A social analysis undertaken 
during project preparation involved various stakeholders. In addition to surveys, national, oblast,

D.  Risks 
 
66.  The Project involves almost no technical risk. The selected interventions have been 
tested and proven effective in the Kyrgyz Republic and internationally. The most significant 
challenge is the efficiency of implementation involving multiple ministries, both national and local 
government  bodies,  and  the  AO.  The  AO  became  an  elected  body  only  recently,  and  its

committee comprising representatives of concerned ministries and project oblasts to provide 
policy  guidance.  The  Project  has  made  substantial  provisions  for  supporting  AOs  through 
training and CFCs during the first 2 years of project implementation.  
 
67.  Another challenge is sustainability of the services after project completion. Maintaining

A.  Introduction 
 
1.  Early childhood development (ECD) is inherently multisectoral because young children 
are holistic in their development. Their physical, emotional, social, and cognitive development

centrally  during  the  former  Soviet  Union  (FSU)  and,  until  its  final  years,  were  relatively

services. Scarce resources are concentrated in major cities and towns.Training and supplies

followed the definitions of the World Health Organization (WHO), reported an IMR of 61 per

D.  Summary 
 
14.   ECD services in the Kyrgyz Republic are in short supply, often of poor quality, and 
inaccessible to most poor families because of distance or fees.  Investments in these services 
do not reliably reach areas where poor families predominate, and when they do, fees and costs 
are insurmountable barriers to families and children who need the services most and would 
benefit most from them. Targeted investments to reach poor young children, including in remote

ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL SUSTAINABLITY ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Methodology and Approach 
 
1.  This economic analysis was undertaken in accordance with the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects. The analysis is based on the 
project interventions outlined in the project framework (Appendix 1). It describes the economic 
rationale  and  target  beneficiaries,  provides  with-and  without  project  analysis,  establishes 
economic benefits and economic costs, and compares the economic internal rate of return 
(EIRR) with the economic opportunity cost of capital, which is assumed to be 10%.1 Sensitivity 
analysis tests changes in the EIRR with modified assumptions about project costs and benefits. 
The period of analysis covers 20 years period carried out in constant 2002 dollar prices.    
 
B.  Project Objectives and Scope 
 
2.  The project objectives and components are described in the main text. The three project 
oblasts of Jalal-Abad, Naryn, and Osh have a population of 2.9 million (69% of the country’s 
population), of whom about 2 million live in rural areas. The Project will improve access to 
quality health and education services for the rural population, thereby directly or indirectly 
improving the health and education status of some 484,440 children living in the 12 poorest 
raions of the target oblasts, including children born during the 20-year period. 
 
3.  Improvements in infant and child mortality in the target raions are based on targets 
consistent with the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) for the Kyrgyz Republic by 2015. 
The Project aims to contribute to the MDG targets of reducing by two thirds the infant mortality 
rate (IMR) from 61.3 (1997) to 20.8 (2015) and the under 5 mortality rate (U5MR), from 72.3 to 
24.6 in the same period.   
 
C.  Rationale for Investment and Approach 
 
4.  The economic rationale for investing in early childhood development (ECD) is strong. 
Investment in ECD will improve an individual’s future prospect of earning. The improvement will 
contribute to individual wealth and poverty reduction, increase future productivity of the labor 
force, and lead to economic development. Numerous studies demonstrate that improved health, 
education, and poverty that impact the first several years of children’s development are directly 
related to improved adult and societal productivity. The early years of human life are a critical 
period  during  which  the  foundations  for  healthy  physical,  cognitive,  emotional,  and  social 
development are laid. Neuroscience has revealed the importance for brain development of a 
child’s health, activities, and experiences in the first few years of life. Children who are deprived 
of appropriate stimulation, care, and nutrition during their early years often develop poorly and 
cannot reach their full potential. Although not always impossible, it is very difficult and expensive 
to alter the outcomes of this critical period in later life. Some deficits, for example, iodine and 
iron deficiency, cause irreversible damage. 
 
5.  Investment in ECD benefits not only children and their families, but also society as a 
whole.  Society  benefits  from  ECD  through  greater  productivity  in  later  life.  The  child  care 
programs  free  up  women  to  work  and  thus  increase  the  availability  of  the  labor  force. 
Investment in ECD is also preventive and can reduce the need for and costs of social welfare

programs, and public expenditures in the health care system. Children who benefit from health 
and nutrition interventions and preschool experiences are more likely to enroll and persist in 
school, to be healthier, to need fewer social protection or criminal justice services, and to earn 
higher incomes as adults. Research shows a positive correlation of ill health as a child, and 
physical impairments and health problems later in life, all of which are burdens on health 
services.  ECD also addresses the important societal concern of equity. ECD is known to have a 
larger impact on deprived children than better-off children. Therefore, ECD will contribute to 
narrow  differences  in  development  among  children  who  come  from  various  economic 
backgrounds. This is especially important for the Kyrgyz Republic and other former Soviet Union 
countries where economic inequality is widening.  
 
6.  Integrated  Approach.  Health,  nutrition,  education,  and  home  care  are  interactive 
determinants of child outcomes, and therefore programs to optimize child development should 
integrate these features. Experience shows that integrated ECD interventions are more effective 
than isolated single sector intervention. Young children are very susceptible to infections and 
diseases, and this vulnerability is greater when a child is malnourished. Malnutrition, illness, or 
neglect during childhood has immediate and long-term effects on cognitive development and 
learning achievement through loss of concentration, apathy, and reduced activity. Children who 
are malnourished or neglected during early childhood are more likely to delay enrollment in 
primary  school;  they  are  likely  to  perform  less  well  and  to  learn  less  than  well-nourished 
children.  
 
7.  Community-Based Approach. The preschool system in the former Soviet Union was a 
distinctly center-based approach that prevented the involvement of communities and parents in 
child development, and imposed centrally planned standardized curriculum. The center-based 
approach was an expensive model. The existing state-run kindergartens are not a financially 
viable option for endeavor the Ministry of Education and Culture’s (MOEC) to increase the 
coverage of preschool. The annual expenditure per child in a kindergarten in Jalal-Abad was 
$60-100 equivalent in 2000. The Government budget covers between 65% and over 90% of the 
expenditure, depending on the oblast, and pays mostly for teachers' salaries. By contrast, the 
community-based  preschool  programs  introduced  under  the  Project  expects  the  per  child 
annual recurrent expenditure of a community/home-based preschool to be $30-40 in addition to 
the initial $1,500-2,000 investment on equipment, furniture, and learning materials. With the 
Project, household expenditures on health care due to child morbidity will decline. Increased 
access to preschool programs may increase total expenditures on preschool programs by both 
household and government in the end, but will substantially reduce the expenditure per child 
who benefits from preschool programs.   
 
D.  Cost Benefit Analysis

in ADB’s Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects. The analysis uses domestic prices

costs and benefits. The period of analysis covered 20 years and was carried out in constant 
2002 dollar prices. To simplify the calculation, the analysis focused on benefits from the Project 
in  the  12  project  raions,  while  some  project  activities  including  immunization  and  policy 
development will benefit children across the country.

21.  The economic and social implications of not undertaking the ECD Project are serious 
given the recent trends in poverty, health, and education services in the Kyrgyz Republic. ECD 
investments are among the most effective means interrupting of the intergenerational transfer of 
poverty. The analysis shows a high EIRR of 63.6% can be expected from the Project. If 
immunization and other benefits for children outside the 12 Project raions are factored in, the 
EIRR would be even higher. However, caution is needed in interpreting the EIRR. As the 
economic returns of ECD interventions will largely materialize over a long term, estimation of 
economic returns inevitably relies on a series of assumptions on costs and benefits of the 
interventions, and external factors such as economic growth. Some economic benefits of ECD

estimation.  Sensitivity  analyses  indicate  a  high  variability  of  the  EIRR  due  to  different
